question: How does the battery performance and longevity compare between mirrorless cameras and DSLRs when shooting multiple photos?
generated_answer: When shooting multiple photos, DSLRs generally have better battery performance and longevity compared to mirrorless cameras. This is because DSLRs use a mirror to reflect the image onto a separate sensor for focusing, which allows them to operate without the need for a constantly powered LCD screen or electronic viewfinder. In contrast, mirrorless cameras rely on an electronic viewfinder or LCD screen for composition and focusing, which consumes more battery power. However, advancements in mirrorless technology are gradually narrowing this gap, and some mirrorless cameras now offer comparable battery life to DSLRs.
ground_truth_answer: DSLR cameras have superior battery life compared to mirrorless cameras. A fully charged DSLR battery can typically take 600-800 shots, with some powerful models like Nikon D7200 capable of up to 1100 shots. In contrast, mirrorless cameras have weaker batteries that only last for about 300-400 shots, requiring photographers to carry spare batteries. This is why mirrorless camera users typically pack three batteries for each shoot - one in the camera and two fully charged spares in the bag.
